doc.title: Upside To European Steel Prices On Stronger Demand And Policy Risks; Revising Up Q4 2025 Iron Ore Forecast
doc.source_uri: 2025-09-02/Upside To European Steel Prices On Stronger Demand And Policy Risks; Revising Up Q4 2025 Iron Ore Forecast_2025-09-02

passages.text: We update our iron ore and global steel supply and demand balances, and raise our Q4 2025 iron ore price forecast to \(\) 95/t\(prev.\) \ \(90/t\) . This reflects the iron ore market remaining more balanced than we expected in recent months, as higher steel prices have supported steel output, and therefore iron ore demand.

In line with our longstanding expectations, there have so far been no signs of substantial production cuts in the Chinese steel industry, and instead the headline- driven higher prices have exacerbated the domestic oversupply of steel. Reflecting this, we expect the \(\sim 15\%\) rally in domestic steel prices that occurred in June/July to continue to fade over the coming months, putting the pressure back on steelmaking margins and therefore on raw materials prices.

As the negative outlook for Chinese steel production comes up against a continued ramp- up of new low- cost iron ore supply in 2026, we expect Chinese iron ore port stocks to build by a significant 48Mt in 2026, bringing the iron ore price down to \(\) 80/t\(by the end of next year.

We are more optimistic for ex- China steel markets in 2026 as demand growth and lower Chinese exports lift international steel prices. We expect China's share of global crude steel production to decline to \(51\%\) next year, down from a peak of \(57\%\) in 2020.

In the US, while a weak physical steel market continues to cap near- term prices, we do not expect major exemptions to the Section 232 tariff to come this year, and eventually domestic prices will need to rise to reflect the \(50\%\) tariff rate.

In Europe, we see continued upside to steel prices following the recent rally, as fundamentals improve and given upside risk from the implementation of the EU's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism and potential changes to EU steel import quotas. We open a trade recommendation to go long Q1 2026 North European Hot Rolled Coil Futures, currently trading at 636euro/t.

Prices And Steelmaking Margins To Move Lower As Market Drifts Back Towards Oversupply: We continue to expect the iron ore price to fall from the current level of \(\) 102\(/t over the remainder of 2025, but raise our Q4 2025 average price forecast to\) \ \(95 / t\) (vs. our prior forecast of \(\) 90/t).\(With steelmaking margins and output supported in recent months by the anti - involution - driven rally in prices, the seaborne iron ore market has remained balanced in Q3, vs. our previous expectation of a 6M t build in China port stocks. However, our base case view remains that significant and widespread production or capacity cuts are unlikely to be enforced in the steel industry in the near term, meaning that the support to steel prices should fade over the coming months, putting the pressure back on steelmaking margins and therefore raw materials prices, including iron ore. This will be accompanied by the ramp - up of new low - cost iron ore supply, and we expect iron ore port stocks in China - largely flat over the past two quarters - to return to an uptrend in Q4 2025, and build by a significant 48M t in 2026 (Exhibit 2), acting as the main drag on our iron ore price forecast. As a result, we maintain our 2026 year - end iron ore price forecast of\) \ \(80 / t\)
Exhibit 1: Our 2026 Iron Ore Price Forecast Sits \(8\%\) Below The Futures Curve
Source: Bloomberg, Goldman Sachs, Goldman Investment Research
Exhibit 2: China Iron Ore Port Stocks Could Rise By Almost 50Mt Next Year As New Low-Cost Supply Is Met By A Decline In Seaborne Demand
Source: Mysteel, China NBS, World Steel Association, Wood Mackenzie, Company data, LSEG Data & Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

No Signs Of China Steel Production Cuts: In line with our longstanding expectations, there have so far been no signs of substantial production cuts in the Chinese steel industry, despite the government seeking to tackle overcapacity issues and excessive price competition across many industrial sectors, including steel. Mysteel- reported hot metal and finished steel output has been stable since May, lining up with flat port stocks and an increase in domestic steel inventory. If anything, the improved steelmaking margins and risk that cuts are eventually enforced have instead kept steel output at a high level (Exhibit 3), worsening the domestic oversupply of steel despite steel exports holding up better than expected; flat steel inventory is now at the upper limit of the 10- year (excluding 2024) range (Exhibit 4).

Our view remains that significant production cuts are unlikely to be enforced because (1) economic growth headwind likely to intensify over the remainder of the year and (2) labour market weakness is more severe than during the 2016- 18 period of supply- side reform. Both factors likely discourage local governments from forcing industry closures. This in line with our China economists' view of the impact of anti- involution policies more broadly in the economy. The recent recovery in margins (although not driven by fundamentals) also makes cuts more difficult to justify. As a result, we expect the \(\sim 15\%\) rally in domestic steel prices that occurred in June/July to continue to fade over the coming months, which could see steel production declining due to margin pressure, loosening iron ore market fundamentals. We expect China iron ore consumption to decline by \(1\%\) in 2025, and \(2\%\) next year. While we are more positive for ex- China seaborne demand growth in 2026, at \(+3\%\) , this is not enough to compensate for the China slowdown given that China accounts for \(\sim 80\%\) of the seaborne market.
Exhibit 3: Improved Margins, Driven By Headlines Of Potential Production Cuts, Have Instead Encouraged Higher Hot Metal Output This Year
Source: Mysteel, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 4: We Expect China Domestic Steel Prices And Steelmaking Prices To Move Lower Again As Oversupply Worsens
Source: Mysteel, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

New Low- Cost Supply Exacerbates Surplus: As global seaborne iron ore demand contracts by \(1\%\) in 2026, we expect global supply (excluding India and China domestic) to increase by \(3\%\) , exacerbating the China stock build. These supply additions are driven by Australia, Brazil and West Africa1. The costs of production of these additions sit below our iron ore price forecast, and more than offset the declines we expect from India and China, driven in response to lower prices and China demand respectively. In the near term, we anticipate an increase in Indian net exports following the recovery in iron ore prices over the past two months. However, there is upside risk to our 2026 price forecast if India becomes a net importer at a higher price than we currently anticipate. Currently our model accounts for this happening towards the end of next year as the iron ore price approaches \(80/t\), but the temporary turn to net imports in recent months suggests there is a risk that this could happen at a price level closer to \(90/t\).
Exhibit 5: Indian Net Exports Are Likely To Rebound In September, reflecting The Recent Recovery In Iron Ore Prices
Source: LSEG Data & Analytics, S&P Global Market Intelligence, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 6: Lower China Domestic Supply And Indian Net Exports Only Partially Offset Higher Australian, Brazilian and West African Supply Next Year
Dashed lines are flex supply in our model. The decline in Indian supply is in response to lower iron ore prices and the decline in China domestic supply is in response to lower Chinese demand.
Source: Company data, LSEG Data & Analytics, Wood Mackenzie, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

While we expect China steel demand to continue to contract over the coming years, driven by continued weakness in the construction sector and a slowdown in manufacturing demand growth, we forecast ex- China steel demand to increase. Ex- China apparent steel demand was up by \(1.6\%\) YoY in H1 2025, and we forecast full- year growth of \(2\%\) this year (Exhibit 7), and \(3\%\) in 2026. This is driven both by partial demand recoveries in Europe and the US, alongside continued new growth from India and other Asian (ex- China) emerging markets (Exhibit 8). While still positive, we do expect growth from Asian EMs to be slower in 2025/26 vs. recent years, reflecting slower economic growth.
Exhibit 7: World Ex-China Apparent Steel Demand Was Up By \(1.6\%\) YoY In H1 2025
Source: GTT, World Steel Association, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 8: We Forecast Ex-China Steel Demand To Increase By \(3\%\) In 2026, Driven By Partial Recovery In DMs And New EM Growth
Source: GTT, World Steel Association, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Meanwhile, we have increased our China steel net export forecast for 2025 to \(+6\%\) YoY, as volumes remained resilient in Q2. However, the sequential growth in finished steel exports has now slowed substantially, with semi- finished products driving almost half of the YoY net export growth so far in 2025, despite accounting for only \(4\%\) of China's total

net steel exports last year (Exhibit 9). In 2026, we forecast China's net steel exports to fall by \(21\%\) as headwinds to flat steel exports have increased, including new anti- dumping duties from key importing countries, but at 92Mt will still be \(35\%\) higher than the 10- year average. While China does not export steel directly to the EU, a tightening in EU steel import quotas and the introduction of the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) could also indirectly impact Chinese exports, as many supplying markets of steel to the EU are also major Chinese steel export markets. Combined with higher ex- China production, we see China's share of global crude steel production declining further to \(51\%\) next year, from a peak of \(57\%\) in 2020 (Exhibit 10).
Exhibit 9: Sequential Growth In China's Finished Steel Exports Has Slowed Considerably, With Exporters Turning To Semi-Finished Products
Source: GTT, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 10: We Forecast China's Share Of Global Steel Production To Decline To \(51\%\) In 2026
Source: World Steel Association, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

We see limited price upside to US domestic steel prices in the near term, as a continued weak physical market inhibits producers' ability to increase prices. Despite the increase in the Section 232 steel tariff rate from \(25\%\) to \(50\%\) in June, the domestic US Midwest hot rolled coil spot price is now \(15\%\) below the March peak. Domestic inventory at service sectors remains elevated and steel mill lead times are close to a four- year low (Exhibit 11), providing continued downward pressure on prices. This reflects higher domestic production (Exhibit 12) and weak domestic demand, even though flat steel imports are down by almost \(20\%\) YoY YTD.
Exhibit 11: Low Lead Times Indicate A Still-Weak Physical Market As Production Increases Have Been Met With Muted Demand From Flat Steel-Intensive Sectors
Source: S&P Global Market Intelligence, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 12: Driven By Higher Margins, US Steel Output Is Up \(10\%\) Since The Start Of The Year
Source: AISI, Bloomberg, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

For 2026, we maintain our more positive price outlook for US steel prices. First, we continue to expect an improvement in US domestic demand as US economic activity reaccelerates, and potential inventory rebuild in sectors such as autos and machinery would also support steel consumption. Second, we believe that once demand starts to improve and mill lead times pick up, the full \(50\%\) tariff rate will eventually need to be priced in order to incentivise the small volume of imports required. Currently, domestic prices are only accounting for a tariff rate of \(20 - 30\%\) . While there have been discussions of exemptions in recent months, for example with Mexico and the EU/US "metals alliance," so far there has been no material change to the tariff, and industry consensus is that the tariffs are here to stay. If there are concessions, their size and the country they are given to would drive the price impact, with an exemption to Canada likely the most impactful for HRC prices.

European hot rolled coil prices have rallied by \(5 - 10\%\) from the five- year low over the past month \(^2\) , and we believe that there is further upside to prices ahead. While demand remains subdued for now, down \(1\%\) YoY in H1 2025, we believe that this should turn positive into next year as regional industrial production turns to a cyclical recovery over the coming years, driven by recovering European demand, a fading drag from energy prices and stabilising global economic growth. Meanwhile, after multiple years of destocking (Exhibit 14), the European steel sector is set for a restocking cycle once consumers are confident that prices are on a sustained uptrend.
Exhibit 13: European Steel Prices Remain Close To Five-Year Low, And We Believe There Is Upside To Futures
Source:Bloomberg,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 14: The European Steel Sector Is Set For A Restocking Cycle
Source:EUROFER,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

However, in our view the biggest upside to prices are policy- driven. First, there is the potential for the EU's steel import tariff rate quotas to be reduced, which would raise domestic prices by subjecting more steel import volumes to the full \(25\%\) tariff rate3. The share of net imports as a percentage of regional demand has increased from \(
Exhibit 15: EU Steel Trade Quotas Could Be Tightened Following A Substantial Increase In Net Imports As A Share Of Demand
Source: GTT, World Steel Association, EUROFER, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 16: Despite An Improvement This Year Due To Lower Costs, European Steel Producers Have Struggled To Maintain Pre-Covid Margin Levels Due To A Higher Import Share
Source: Bloomberg, S&P Global Market Intelligence, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 17: Global Iron Ore Supply & Demand Model
Exhibit 18:Global Steel Supply & Demand Model
Source: World Steel Association, NBS, GTT, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
